07_01.question: What is true about creating an entity relationship diagram?

A_07_01.choice: There will be at most seven entities

C_07_01.choice: If you identify more than seven entities, analyze and combine until you have seven or less

D_07_01.choice: There will be at most seven relationships

E_07_01.choice: Entities will have at most seven attributes

07_01.explanation: "Work iteratively and constantly challenge the data model with business rules and exceptions to see whether the diagram is communicating the business system appropriately." (p. 189)

07_02.question: Select all that applies to various normal forms:

A_07_02.choice: A table in 3NF is also in 2NF

B_07_02.choice: A table in 3NF is also in 1NF.

C_07_02.choice: A table in 2NF is also in 1NF.

07_02.explanation:
2NF = 1NF + no partial dependencies
3NF = 2NF + no transitive dependencies

1NF, 2NF, 3NF are successively stricter than the previous.

07_03.question: Relational tables that have a single-attribute PK, are immediately in 2NF.
07_03.explanation:
A relational table is in 2NF if it does not have partial dependencies.

Partial dependency means an attribute depends on only a part of, rather than the whole, primary key.

If the primary key is a single attribute, it has no parts, so there cannot be any partial dependencies.

07_04.question: Some redundancies in a relational DB are necessary.
07_04.explanation:
When normalizing to 3NF, you
1. create a new entity for each transitive dependency
2. remove the dependent attributes from the original entity, but keep the other attributes.
=> The attributes that you don't remove are foreign keys, they are necessary redundancies.

For example, this table
EMP_NUMEMP_NAMEJOB_CLASSWAGE

has a transitive dependency JOB_CLASS --> WAGE, so it's normalized into
EMP_NUMEMP_NAMEJOB_CLASS

JOB_CLASSWAGE

JOB_CLASS in the 1st table is a foreign key. It's redundant with JOB_CLASS in the 2nd table, but necessary to link the 2 tables together.

(module 7, slide 20)

07_05.question: Once we have an ERD, we can be sure we have a good database structure.
07_05.explanation: You also have to normalize it.

07_06.question: The following table is _____

C_07_06.choice: a relational table that is only 1NF

07_06.explanation:
Each row (project) has multiple values (employees), so this table is not 1NF.
2NF requires 1NF, and 3NF requires 2NF, so it can't be the other ones either.

07_07.question: Foreign keys in a relational DB are an example of _____

B_07_07.choice: FKs are not redundancy at all

07_07.explanation:
When normalizing to 3NF, you
1. create a new entity for each transitive dependency
2. remove the dependent attributes from the original entity, but keep the other attributes.
=> The attributes that you don't remove are foreign keys, they are necessary redundancies.

For example, this table
EMP_NUMEMP_NAMEJOB_CLASSWAGE

has a transitive dependency JOB_CLASS --> WAGE, so it's normalized into
EMP_NUMEMP_NAMEJOB_CLASS

JOB_CLASSWAGE

JOB_CLASS in the 1st table is a foreign key. It's redundant with JOB_CLASS in the 2nd table, but necessary to link the 2 tables together.

(module 7, slide 20)

07_08.question: Partial dependency is a form of functional dependency.
07_08.explanation:
AFAIK there's no "non-functional" dependency, all dependencies are functional in one way or another.

Partial dependency is a type of (functional) dependency where the determinant is only part of, rather than the whole, the identifier.

07_09.question: Our goal with normalization is to completely eliminate redundancy.
07_09.explanation:
When normalizing to 3NF, you
1. create a new entity for each transitive dependency
2. remove the dependent attributes from the original entity, but keep the other attributes.
=> The attributes that you don't remove are foreign keys, they are necessary redundancies.

For example, this table
EMP_NUMEMP_NAMEJOB_CLASSWAGE

has a transitive dependency JOB_CLASS --> WAGE, so it's normalized into
EMP_NUMEMP_NAMEJOB_CLASS

JOB_CLASSWAGE

JOB_CLASS in the 1st table is a foreign key. It's redundant with JOB_CLASS in the 2nd table, but necessary to link the 2 tables together.

(module 7, slide 20)

07_10.question: Balance occurs between DFDs and ERDs when the data stores _____

A_07_10.choice: Can be equated to entities on the ERD and when entities are referred to by data stores on the DFD

C_07_10.choice: Have only one input and one output flow

D_07_10.choice: Are named the same as the relationships on the ERD

E_07_10.choice: Can be compared to ERD data flows and attributes on the ERD are included in data stores on the DFD

07_10.explanation:
"The DFD data components need to correspond with the ERD's data stores (i.e., entities) and the data elements that comprise the data flows (i.e., attributes)." (p. 191)

It's a trick question. There's a similar but incorrect choice because "ERD data flows" is not a thing. ERD has entities, only DFD has data flows.

07_11.question: The following table is in 1NF. If we normalize this table to 2NF, how many tables in total would exist in our relational DB after normalizing to 2NF?

07_12.question: Omar has a model with 85 entities. He can do which of the following?

A_07_12.choice: Stop â€“ he has all entities defined

B_07_12.choice: Co-validate the entities with the level 2 DFD diagrams

C_07_12.choice: Compress these into at most seven entity grouping units

E_07_12.choice: Group these into related subject areas

07_12.explanation: "If the model becomes too complex or busy, the model can be broken down into subject areas." (p. 189)

07_13.question: In a functional dependence, the determinant is always a single attribute.
07_13.explanation:
Determinant = the thing the dependent depends on.
Multiple attributes may be required to determine another attribute.
For example, (ISBN, Author_Num) --> Royalty (lab 7.1)

07_14.question: In a functional dependence, the dependent is always a single attribute.
07_14.explanation:
Determinant = the thing the dependent depends on.
There may be multiple dependents. For example, "given an employee's number, we would know their name, job class and charge per hour." (module 7, slide 12)

07_15.question: CRUD stands for create, read, update and delete and can be used to verify DFDs and ERDs.
07_15.explanation: "A useful tool to clearly depict the interrelationship between process and data models is the create, read, update, delete (CRUD) matrix." (p. 192)

07_16.question: A transitive dependency is a form of partial dependency.
07_16.explanation: Transitive means the determinant is a non-identifier. Partial means the determinant is a part of the identifier. These are unrelated.

07_17.question: The following table is in 1NF. If we normalize this table to 2NF, how many tables in total would exist in the resulting DB?
07_17.explanation:
1. MedName --> ShelfLife
2. PatientID --> PatientName
3. (MedName, PatientID, Date) --> (RefillsAllowed, Dosage)

07_18.question: How many non-prime attributes do you see in the following dependency diagram?
07_18.explanation: Non-prime attributes are attributes that aren't identifiers. The identifiers, in this case, are PROJ_NUM and EMP_NUM, meaning the remaining five attributes are non-prime.

07_19.question: Andrew, an analyst for PaxMedia Inc., has just learned that the business rules for a system he has been working on have changed. This means what?

A_07_19.choice: Andrew will be reassigned to a different project that is in its beginning stages

B_07_19.choice: The project will have to be scrapped and restarted

C_07_19.choice: The ERD data model will have to be put on hold while new DFD diagrams are created

D_07_19.choice: The ERD components will have to be changed

E_07_19.choice: Nothing â€“ once the ERD data models have been drawn, they are 'frozen' for the system

07_19.explanation: "When business rules change, the relationships or other data model components will have to be altered." (p. 189)

07_20.question: In a relational table, when we say attribute A functionally defines attribute B (A --> B) , it means that:

A_07_20.choice: A and B must both be part of the PK.

B_07_20.choice: there is only one value of B for any given value of A.

C_07_20.choice: A and B must not be part of the PK.

D_07_20.choice: there is only one value of A for any given value of B.

07_20.explanation: "We say PROJ_NUM functionally defines PROJ_Name, because only one name is associated with any given project number." (module 7, slide 10)
